Sentencas: The poisoning effect by hydrogen chloride (HCl) on state-of-the-art Ni anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) at 750 degrees C is evaluated in either hydrogen or syngas fuel.
Titulo: Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments

Sentencas: Experiments are performed on single cells and short stacks and HCl concentration in the fuel gas is increased from 1 ppm(v) up to 1000 ppm(v) at different current densities.
Titulo: Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments

Sentencas: Characterization methods such as cell voltage monitoring vs. time and electrochemical impedance response analysis (distribution of relaxation times (DRT), equivalent electrical circuit) are used to identify the prevailing degradation mechanism.
Titulo: Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments

Sentencas: Single cell experiments revealed that the poisoning is more severe when feeding with hydrogen than with syngas.
Titulo: Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments

Sentencas: Performance loss is attributed to the effects of HCl adsorption onto nickel surfaces, which lowered the catalyst activity.
Titulo: Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments

Sentencas: Interestingly, in syngas HCl does not affect stack performance even at concentrations up to 500 ppm(v), even when causing severe corrosion of the anode exhaust pipe.
Titulo: Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments

Sentencas: Furthermore, post-test analysis suggests that chlorine is present on the nickel particles in the form of adsorbed chlorine, rather than forming a secondary phase of nickel chlorine.
Titulo: Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments
Solid oxide fuel cell anode degradation by the effect of hydrogen chloride in stack and single cell environments
